questions.text: What is the mode of inheritance of haemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hereditary hemochromatosis is most commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern due to HFE gene mutations on chromosome 6.

Haemochromatosis: features

  • Haemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disorder of iron absorption and metabolism resulting in iron accumulation. It is caused most commonly by inheritance of mutations in the HFE gene on both copies of chromosome 6.

Epidemiology

  • 1 in 10 people of European descent carry a gene mutation affecting iron metabolism, mainly HFE
  • prevalence in people of European descent = 1 in 200

Clinical features

  • Early symptoms include fatigue, erectile dysfunction and arthralgia (often of the hands)
  • 'bronze' skin pigmentation
  • diabetes mellitus
  • liver: stigmata of chronic liver disease, hepatomegaly, cirrhosis, hepatocellular deposition)
  • cardiac failure (2° to dilated cardiomyopathy)
  • hypogonadism (2° to cirrhosis and pituitary dysfunction - hypogonadotropic hypogonadism)
  • arthritis (especially of the hands)

Reversible complications Irreversible complications

Whilst elevated liver function tests and hepatomegaly may be reversible, cirrhosis is not.

Explanation of other options:

X-linked dominant (Option B): No X-linked pattern is associated with HFE mutations.

Mitochondrial inheritance (Option C):Mitochondrial disorders are maternally inherited; not relevant to iron metabolism disorders.

Autosomal dominant (Option D): Although heterozygous carriers may have mild biochemical abnormalities, clinical disease occurs only in homozygotes (recessive).

Key Takeaway: Hereditary hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disorder due to HFE mutations, leading to progressive iron overload and multisystem complications.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of headaches and sweating. Her mother had renal calculi and died of a tumour in her neck. On examination a nodule is felt in the patient's neck in the region of the thyroid gland. A surgeon advises complete thyroidectomy. What is the most important investigation the surgeon must undertake before surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pheochromocytoma must be ruled out prior to thyroidectomy in suspected MEN-2A, as undiagnosed catecholamine excess can lead to perioperative hypertensive crisis.
This patient likely has MEN-2A, characterized by:

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia or adenoma

The presence of thyroid nodule, family history, and symptoms of catecholamine excess (headaches, sweating) strongly suggests MEN-2A.

  • Most crucial preoperative step: Exclude pheochromocytoma
  • Investigations:
    • 24-hour urinary catecholamines or metanephrines
    • If positive → preoperative alpha-blockade (phenoxybenzamine)
    • Only then is thyroid surgery safe

Related Important Points:

  • MEN-2A:

    • Parathyroid hyperplasia
    • Medullary carcinoma of thyroid
    • Pheochromocytoma
  • MEN-2B:
    • Medullary carcinoma thyroid
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus
  • MEN-1:
    • Pituitary adenoma
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors

Explanation of other options:

Serum thyroxine (Option A): Not altered in medullary carcinoma; MTC arises from parafollicular C-cells, not follicular cells.

Serum calcium (Option B): May be elevated if parathyroid disease is present, but not an emergency concern prior to thyroidectomy.

24-h urinary 5-HIAA (Option C): Used to diagnose carcinoid syndrome, not relevant in MEN syndromes or thyroid malignancy.

Key Takeaway: Before surgery in suspected MEN-2A, pheochromocytoma must be ruled out to prevent intraoperative hypertensive crises from unopposed catecholamine release.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with a history of panic attacks, palpitations, sweating, headache and flushing. On examination, his pulse rate is 120 bpm, BP 190/110 mmHg. A blood test shows high levels of noradrenaline. Which of the following tests would be most useful in establishing the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient most probably has a pheochromocytoma. The presence of noradrenaline alone usually indicates an extra-adrenal tumour.

  • Scanning with [131I] metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) produces specific uptake in sites of sympathetic activity with about 90% success.
  • It is particularly useful with extra-adrenal tumours. CT and MRI scans are useful in detecting adrenal tumours.
  • An ultrasound scan is the least sensitive modality and is thus not preferred.
  • Secondary hypertension may occur due to unilateral renal artery stenosis but is unlikely to be associated with these clinical features.

Related Important Points:

  • MEN-2A: MTC, pheochromocytoma, parathyroid hyperplasia
  • MEN-2B: MTC, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus
  • MEN-1: Pituitary adenoma, parathyroid hyperplasia, pancreatic tumors
  • Other investigations such as serum thyroxine or 5-HIAA are unlikely to be associated with these clinical features.

Explanation of other options:

Ultrasound scan (Option A): Least sensitive, especially for retroperitoneal or small adrenal tumors

CT scan (Option B): Good for adrenal localization but less specific; cannot confirm functional status

Renal arteriography (Option C): Used to evaluate renal artery stenosis, not useful for diagnosing catecholamine-secreting tumors

Key Takeaway: MIBG scanning is the investigation of choice for localizing extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas, especially when noradrenaline is elevated.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma. Screening with pentagastrin testing suggests that she has medullary thyroid carcinoma, and you plan a thyroidectomy. What anti-hypertensive medication should be started before surgery for a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phenoxybenzamine, a long-acting non-selective alpha-blocker, is the first-line agent for preoperative blood pressure control in pheochromocytoma.

  • Phenoxybenzamine is a more potent alpha-blocker than doxazosin and is the recommended choice for initial anti-hypertensive medication in pheochromocytoma where surgery is contemplated. It should be given in divided doses, at 20 mg initially, increasing to 80 mg.
  • Patients should then be considered for additional β-blockade with propranolol, again in divided doses up to 240 mg/day. Always start with a blockade first, as initial use of β-blockers may worsen hypertension. Labetalol is not recommended.

Explanation of other options:

Atenolol (Option B): A beta-blocker; contraindicated as first-line due to risk of unopposed alpha vasoconstriction

Labetalol (Option C): Has both alpha and beta-blocking activity, but beta effect predominates, making it less safe preoperatively

Doxazosin (Option D): A selective alpha-1 blocker; can be used if phenoxybenzamine is unavailable, but less effective for complete pre-op blockade

Key Takeaway: Phenoxybenzamine is the drug of choice for preoperative alpha-blockade in pheochromocytoma to prevent intraoperative hypertensive crisis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is being investigated for suspected MEN-2b syndrome. She is also noted to have Marfanoid features. What will be the most characteristic finding in a blood test in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

MEN-2B is classically associated with pheochromocytoma, and hence elevated plasma metanephrines are a hallmark laboratory finding.

  • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN-2B) is a rare, autosomal dominant syndrome that includes:
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)-often aggressive and early onset
  • Pheochromocytoma - causing excess catecholamines → elevated plasma/urine metanephrines
  • Mucosal neuromas - typically on lips, tongue, conjunctiva
  • Marfanoid habitus - tall, long limbs, high-arched palate
  • Parathyroid involvement is uncommon (unlike MEN-2A)

The most reliable and characteristic lab abnormality is elevated metanephrines, due to catecholamine-secreting tumors.

Explanation of other options:

Elevated serum calcium (Option A): More typical of MEN-1 or MEN-2A due to parathyroid hyperplasia, not MEN-2B.

Elevated thyroxine (Option C): Thyroxine is not elevated in medullary thyroid carcinoma, as it arises from parafollicular C-cells, not follicular cells.

Decreased parathyroid hormone (Option D): MEN-2B does not cause hypoparathyroidism; parathyroid abnormalities are uncommon.

Key Takeaway: MEN-2B features marfanoid habitus, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma, with elevated metanephrines as the key diagnostic lab clue.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of deteriorating physical performance at work, associated with dysarthria and clumsiness. On examination, he looks pale, has hepatomegaly and Kayser-Fleischer rings in the cornea. What would be the most important investigation to support the suspected clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Liver biopsy with quantitative copper estimation (>250 µg/g dry weight) is the most definitive test to confirm Wilson disease. This patient has classic features of Wilson disease, a disorder of impaired copper excretion, due to ATP7B mutation.

Key findings:

  • Neurological signs (dysarthria, clumsiness)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • KF rings, seen in >99% with neuro features

According to both Harrison 21st ed and the diagnostic algorithm, if ceruloplasmin is low and KF rings are present with elevated 24-hr urinary copper:

  • Liver biopsy is performed to confirm diagnosis, showing:
    • Liver copper >250 µg/g dry weight
    • Histology consistent with copper accumulation (rhodanine stain)

Explanation of other options:

CT scan of the brain (Option A): May show basal ganglia changes, but not diagnostic for Wilson disease

Serum ceruloplasmin level (Option C): Often decreased, but low in only ~90%; not confirmatory alone

CRP level (Option D): Irrelevant to diagnosis; nonspecific inflammatory marker

Key Takeaway: Liver biopsy with copper quantification is the most definitive investigation for confirming Wilson disease, especially when KF rings and neurologic signs are present.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about acute intermittent porphyria (AIP)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is an autosomal dominant disorder of hepatic heme synthesis, not recessive. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase (also called hydroxymethylbilane synthase or HMB-synthase), leading to the accumulation of porphyrin precursors.

  • Characterized by intermittent neurovisceral attacks: abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric features, seizures
  • Symptoms are often precipitated by drugs (e.g. barbiturates, phenytoin), infections, hormonal changes, fasting, and stress
  • Urinary porphobilinogen (PBG) increases during and between attacks
  • Photosensitivity is not typical (unlike other porphyrias)
  • Urine may turn dark red on standing

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway: Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is an autosomal dominant disorder of heme synthesis with neurovisceral symptoms and red urine, triggered by environmental and hormonal factors.

questions.text: Which of the following hepatic porphyrias present during adult life?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

AIP, HCP, and VP are all acute hepatic porphyrias that present in adult life with neurovisceral symptoms and elevated porphyrin precursors.

Hepatic porphyrias are disorders caused by enzymatic defects in the heme biosynthesis pathway in the liver. The four acute hepatic porphyrias include:

  • Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP)
  • Hereditary coproporphyria (HCP)
  • Variegate porphyria (VP)
  • ALA-dehydratase porphyria (ADP) - rarer, may present in infancy or adolescence
  • These porphyrias typically manifest after puberty, most often in early adulthood
  • Clinical features include:
    • Acute neurovisceral attacks (abdominal pain, seizures, confusion)
    • Autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension)
    • In HCP and VP, photosensitivity may also be seen
  • Diagnosis is made by detecting elevated aminolevulinic acid (ALA) and porphobilinogen (PBG) in urine
  • Common triggers: Drugs, stress, fasting, hormonal shifts, infection

Explanation of other options:

AIP (Option A): Most common acute hepatic porphyria, presents in adult females

HCP (Option B): Manifests with both cutaneous and neurovisceral symptoms in adults

VP (Option C): Similar presentation, with cutaneous and neurological involvement in adulthood

Key Takeaway:

All three - AIP, HCP, and VP- are hepatic porphyrias that present during adult life, often triggered by environmental or hormonal stressors.

questions.text: Which of the following best relates to Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Nazer index is the specific prognostic tool for Wilson's disease, especially in acute liver failure, guiding decisions regarding liver transplantation.
The Nazer prognostic index is used to assess prognosis in Wilson's disease with fulminant hepatic failure.

  • It includes 3 parameters:
    • Serum bilirubin
    • AST (Aspartate aminotransferase)
    • Prothrombin time prolongation (seconds)
  • Scoring interpretation:
    • Score <7 → Medical management usually sufficient
    • Score ≥9 → Indication for urgent liver transplantation

It helps in timely transplant referral, especially in young patients presenting with rapid deterioration and encephalopathy.

Explanation of other options:

International Prognostic Index (IPI) (Option A): Used for non-Hodgkin lymphoma prognosis.

Hasford prognostic system (Option B): Designed for chronic myeloid leukemia.

Nottingham prognostic index (Option C): Applied in breast cancer, based on tumor size, grade, and lymph node involvement.

Key Takeaway:

The Nazer index is a validated prognostic tool in Wilson's disease, helping assess severity and guide transplant decisions.

Explanation:

PCT is the most prevalent porphyria worldwide, and it primarily presents with photosensitive skin lesions. Porphyrias are classified based on the site of heme precursor accumulation:

  • Hepatic porphyrias: AIP, HCP, VP, PCT
  • Erythropoietic porphyrias: Congenital erythropoietic porphyria, erythropoietic protoporphyria

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the:

  • Most common porphyria overall
  • Caused by a deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase
  • Precipitated by: alcohol, hepatitis C, estrogens, iron overload

Clinical features:

  • Chronic blistering photosensitivity on sun-exposed areas (esp. dorsum of hands and face)
  • Hyperpigmentation, skin fragility, and sclerodermoid changes
  • No abdominal or neurologic symptoms (unlike AIP)

Explanation of other options:

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) (Option B): Most common acute hepatic porphyria, but not the most common overall.

Hereditary coproporphyria (HCP) (Option C): Rare, presents with neurovisceral and cutaneous symptoms.

Variegate porphyria (VP) (Option D): Also less common, with mixed features but not the most prevalent.

Key Takeaway:

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common porphyria, characterized by blistering photosensitivity and cutaneous findings.
